name: muehlenbeckia
country-or-region-of-origin: West N America, S America, C America, Australasia, Indian Ocean
distribution: These plants are now found in almost every area of the world.
light: Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
flower-description: The flowers on these plants range from nearly invisible to eye catching. They appear at the ends of the stems singly, in ones and twos and sometimes in a raceme. Individually they are small and simple in shape. It is when they appear in a raceme or a cluster that you notice them. The color ranges from white, through yellow to green and every combination of those three colors that you can imagine. Some species are dioecious, like holly, so you would have to plant both sexes to get fruit.
leaf-description: The leaves on these plants are usually deciduous but some are semi-evergreen. The shapes vary from round to lanceolate with some species having entire margins and some wavy ones. They are usually green in color.
stem-description: Thin wiry black stems that are very tough.
uses: Some of the species of this genus native to South America have been used by the indigenous peoples as medicines.
